Good Hamlet: And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark....
Why seems it so particular with thee?
Let not thy mother lose her prayers
I pray thee stay with us

cast thy nighted colour off: he hath much talk'd of you

Good Hamlet: And sure I am two men there are not living...
And I beseech you instantly to visit...
I doubt it is no other but the main
His father's death and our o'erhasty marriage.
Came this from Hamlet to her?
But look where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.
The lady doth protest too much
I'll warrant you; fear me not. Withdraw; I hear him coming.

cast thy nighted colour off: thou hast thy father much offended.

column3: you answer with an idle tongue.

cast thy nighted colour off: then I'll set those to you that can speak.

Good Hamlet: What wilt thou do? Thou wilt not murther me?

cast thy nighted colour off: what a rash and bloody deed is this!

Good Hamlet: What have I done that thou dar'st wag thy tongue
In noise so rude against me?
That roars so loud and thunders in the index?
Thou turn'st mine eyes into my very soul
These words like daggers enter in mine ears....
That you do bend your eye on vacancy
To whom do you speak this?
Nothing at all; yet all that is I see.
This is the very coinage of your brain.

cast thy nighted colour off: thou hast cleft my heart in twain.
if words be made of breath
I have no life to breathe...

Good Hamlet: I had forgot! 'Tis so concluded on.
Bestow this place on us a little while.
Mad as the sea and wind when both contend
Which is the mightier. In his lawless fit...
To draw apart the body he hath kill'd;
I will not speak with her.
How cheerfully on the false trail they cry!
One woe doth tread upon another's heel
So fast they follow. Your sister's drown'd
There is a willow grows aslant a brook
That shows his hoar leaves in the glassy stream....
And thus a while the fit will work on him....

cast thy nighted colour off: my lord; I pray you pardon me. Drinks.

column3: the drink! O my dear Hamlet!
